author: By Carlos Lozada, Pamela Paul and Derek Arthur
title: Two Opinion Columnists on Melania Trump’s Memoir
description: Pamela Paul and Carlos Lozada dig into the former first lady’s “book-adjacent object.”
content: Melania Trump promoted her recent memoir, “Melania,” with a series of glossy and cryptic promotional videos stating the desire “to share my perspective: the truth.” But what does the self-titled memoir reveal to us about the often inscrutable former first lady? The bookish Opinion columnists Carlos Lozada and Pamela Paul discuss what they learned — and often, what they did not — from her work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Abortion Could Decide Control of State Supreme Courts
description: In Michigan, Ohio, Arizona and elsewhere, progressive court candidates are hoping that the abortion issue that helped conservatives remake the federal judiciary will work for them this time.
content: The fight over the right to an abortion has expanded into yet another corner of American political life: the races to fill seats on state supreme courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Schwarz
title: The Mystery That’s Too Good to Solve
description: Who built the Shell Grotto, and why do we care so much?
content: Six years ago, during a trip to the seaside town Margate, England, my family and I visited a site known as the Shell Grotto. When it first opened to the public, in 1838, it was advertised as an unexplained mystery. Apparently workmen had stumbled upon the “curious and interesting sight” while digging in the garden of a cottage. Further investigation revealed a subterranean network of passages and a chamber covered in approximately 4.6 million seashells, laid out to form a 2,000-square-foot mosaic spanning walls and archways and a domed shaft that lets in a narrow beam of light. Today the shells — round winkles, long razor clams, mussels, other less familiar specimens — are mostly faded in color, some blackened with dirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Human Sports Referees Be Mostly Replaced With Automated Ones?
description: The United States’ big professional sports leagues are moving toward technological systems for officiating games. Is that a good thing?
content: Do you play or watch sports? Have you seen a referee or umpire make a really bad call? Have those bad calls ever made you wish a computer was making the calls instead of a person?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. Warns it May Cut Israel’s Military Aid
description: Plus, an investigation into China’s panda breeding program.
content: The United States has sent a letter to Israel warning that the country could lose military aid if it did not increase the flow of humanitarian supplies into Gaza within the next 30 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Hollywood and Bollywood Kick Off Diwali in New York
description: Hasan Minhaj, Mira Nair and Nora Fatehi joined business and entertainment leaders of South Asian descent at the Pierre hotel in their most elegant attire.
content: Fifteen years ago, Anjula Acharia hosted an intimate Diwali party with about 40 guests in her TriBeCa apartment. She wanted to invite her friends to celebrate the Hindu festival of lights, which she grew up observing with her family in Buckinghamshire, England, a suburb roughly 50 miles northwest of London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: A Climate Resistant Community Passed Two Hurricane Tests
description: On the west coast of Florida, a town built to weather hurricanes hosted more than 2,000 people during Hurricane Milton. Could communities like this help shape Florida’s future?
content: As Hurricane Milton rushed ashore last Wednesday at least 2,000 Floridians found safe haven at Babcock Ranch, a community the size of Manhattan that  opened in 2018 to withstand climate-driven storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Understanding Canada’s Fight With India Over a Murdered Sikh Activist
description: The diplomatic rift has suddenly grown more stark as Canada amplifies its accusations that India is directing lethal operations abroad.
content: Canada expelled six Indian diplomats on Monday, including India’s High Commissioner to Canada, accusing them of being part of a broad criminal network to intimidate and harass Canadian Sikhs. India responded by kicking out six Canadian diplomats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: How a Man Imprisoned in New York Could Sway a Key House Race in Alaska
description: Eric Hafner, who is serving a 20-year sentence, is running to represent a state in which he has never set foot. He could play the spoiler under Alaska’s ranked-choice system.
content: In the race for Alaska’s sole seat in the House of Representatives, candidates are defined by credentials specific to the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frøydis Fossli Moe
title: How Do You Say Goodbye to an Abusive Family Member?
description: How do you cope when an abusive family member becomes terminally ill?
content: When I was 19 years old, I cut ties with my father. I had a difficult, painful childhood, and I needed distance from him in order to heal. When I was 29 years old, I learned he had received a terminal diagnosis, and I had to confront the relationship I’d tried to leave behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Night Sky
description: What is the coolest thing you have seen in the night sky?
content: Last week, people in parts of the northern hemisphere caught a rare glimpse of the aurora borealis, also known as the northern lights. The visual display was set off by a geomagnetic storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Yan Zhuang
title: Hong Kong Investigates After 9 Monkeys Die in a Zoo
description: The zoo partially closed after the deaths, which occurred over two days and included members of a critically endangered species.
content: The deaths of nine monkeys at a Hong Kong zoo over two days have prompted officials to close part of the zoo as they investigate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek, Abu Bakr Bashir and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: In Embattled Gaza, a Woman Chooses Her Mother Over Evacuating
description: Amna Soliman says she can’t leave her mother, who is in a wheelchair, so she stays, despite heavy fighting and repeated warnings to leave.
content: With Israeli tanks close, shrapnel pinging off the external walls of her home and the booms of airstrikes sounding nearby, Amna Soliman would like to heed a recent Israeli military warning to evacuate. But it’s not that simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: I Ate at Every Carbone in America. Was It Worth the Trip?
description: A decade after the first one opened, the Italian American juggernaut is still a celebrity magnet and impossible reservation. Take our red-sauce tour.
content: Carbone is a luxury brand, a celebrity beacon, a theatrical production, an indoor theme park celebrating the meatball-topped maximalism of Italian American cuisine and pop culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Seeks to Line Up Billions in Financing as Strike Goes On
description: The aerospace giant said it could raise as much as $25 billion in debt or equity over the next three years, including a $10 billion line of credit.
content: Boeing on Tuesday announced steps to improve its financial position as costs mounted and a strike by its largest union entered its second month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Bianca Pallaro
title: Eric Adams’s Campaign Donations Plunge After Federal Indictment
description: Donations to the New York City mayor’s re-election campaign ceased after a five-count federal corruption indictment against him was unsealed last month.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York saw donations to his re-election campaign take a nosedive after his federal indictment last month on five counts of bribery, fraud and soliciting illegal foreign campaign donations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
title: Trump Brags About His Math Skills and Economic Plans. Experts Say Both Are Shaky.
description: In a combative interview, the former president hinted at even higher tariffs as an economic magic bullet.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has been offering up new tax cuts to nearly every group of voters that he meets in recent weeks, shaking the nerves of budget watchers and fiscal hawks who fear his expensive economic promises will explode the nation’s already bulging national debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: A Pro-Trump Ad Looks to Turn Harris’s Record as a Prosecutor Against Her
description: The spot from one of the biggest super PACs backing Donald Trump portrays Kamala Harris as a radical leftist, especially on crime — channeling a G.O.P. law-and-order message that dates back to Nixon.
content: MAGA Inc., one of the biggest super PACs supporting Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, has aired this 30-second ad on television stations in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan and Pennsylvania over the past week at a cost, so far, of around $4.4 million, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman
title: Iranian General Is Seen in State Media After Questions Over His Whereabouts
description: Brig. Gen. Esmail Ghaani, commander of the elite Quds Force, appeared in video footage on Tuesday as Tehran braces for a possible counterstrike by Israel.
content: After days of speculation about his whereabouts, Brig. Gen. Esmail Ghaani, the commander of Iran’s elite Quds Force, appeared in video footage broadcast by Iranian state news media and in photographs from independent news outlets on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Chestnut Championship in England Is Roiled by Accusation of Cheating
description: Buckeye chestnuts, known as conkers in Britain, are played in an annual championship there. This year, there are accusations of cheating. And it’s all very serious.
content: Buckle up, because a cheating scandal is roiling England. The accusations revolve around a winner of the World Conker Championships, and if he used a metal conker to defeat his opponents’ conkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Is Bone Broth Really Brimming With Health Benefits?
description: It’s called “liquid gold” on TikTok. We asked experts if there’s any science behind the health claims.
content: Q: I’ve heard that bone broth has a ton of health benefits. Is there any truth to that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nicholas Fandos, Eric Krupke, Mooj Zadie, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: Two Blue States That Will Determine Control of Congress
description: New York and California have become unlikely focal points in the fight for control of the House.
content: This year’s presidential race looks certain to be won or lost in a handful of swing states where neither party has a clear advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annemarie Conte
title: In These D.I.Y. Groups, ‘You Don’t Have to Prove That You Belong’
description: With help from online tutorials, Facebook groups and in-person workshops, home improvement is becoming far more inclusive to people beyond straight men.
content: Kayla Nelson was perched on a ladder in her bedroom installing picture-frame molding in a recent Instagram Reel. The rhythmic guh-gunk of the nail gun she was using was overridden by the soundtrack of Megan Thee Stallion’s “Where Them Girls At.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: There Is No Crying in Baseball (Except Over This Hat)
description: Mets and Yankees fans seem to agree: Mayor Eric Adams’s both-sides baseball cap struck out.
content: This was supposed to be a golden, glorious week for New York baseball fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: City Ballet Ends Its Season With a Prayer and a Romantic Romp
description: The fall season wrapped up with an excellent program featuring works by Balanchine and Ratmansky, as well as a celebration of Justin Peck’s 10th year as resident choreographer.
content: There is a time for dancing, and there is a time for applause. Sometimes they happen concurrently, but that isn’t ideal. George Balanchine, the founding choreographer of New York City Ballet, viewed the theater as a church. “You don’t applaud in the middle of a sermon or choral hymn,” he was quoted as saying in a book about the making of “Mozartiana,” his last major work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 15, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about mail ballot regulations described incorrectly Pennsylvania procedures for detecting whether mailed-in ballots are properly enclosed in privacy sleeves. Election officials can check for the sleeves using pre-punched holes in ballot envelopes before Election Day; they do not have to wait until they open the envelopes on Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: Tim Berne, a D.I.Y. Jazz Institution
description: The saxophonist and composer has spent 50 years in the New York scene. As he turns 70, he’s commanding gigs at a Brooklyn bar and continuing to inspire.
content: For the saxophonist and composer Tim Berne, the Brooklyn bar Lowlands is a favorite neighborhood hangout. Lately, it has also become his musical laboratory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Asked About Conversations With Putin, Trump Dodges: ‘I Don’t Talk About That’
description: The former president, who once pushed to prosecute a former secretary of state for talking with foreign officials, said that it would be “a good thing” for himself to have secretly kept in touch with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia — if he did.
content: When he was president, Donald J. Trump grew incensed that former Secretary of State John Kerry still talked with foreign officials after leaving office — so much so, in fact, that he tried to have Mr. Kerry thrown in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Meet the Election Denier Forecasting the 2024 Race
description: Seth Keshel has become a darling among election deniers by factoring widespread voter fraud — the existence of which has been widely debunked — into his election predictions.
content: Election forecasters think this year’s presidential race is too close to call. Nevada? A complete tossup. Pennsylvania? Anybody’s guess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Prices Fall After Israel Reportedly Says It Won’t Target Iran’s Nuclear or Oil Facilities
description: Brent crude, the international benchmark, was trading at below $74 a barrel on Tuesday, a drop from the $80 range.
content: Oil prices fell about 5 percent Tuesday on reports that Israel had assured the Biden administration that it did not intend to attack Iranian nuclear sites or oil infrastructure. Brent crude, the international benchmark, was trading at below $74 a barrel on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 493
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 16, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Liz Alderman
title: Chinese Automakers Display Force at Paris Auto Show
description: Weeks after Europe imposed additional tariffs on electric vehicles made in China, the country’s car companies were defiant at France’s leading auto event.
content: China’s ambitions to become a force in the European car market were on full display this week at the Paris Motor Show, where a record number of the country’s automakers unveiled cutting-edge electric models despite a recent European Union decision to impose anti-subsidy tariffs on their vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Paris Is Rising as an Art Market Hub, With Some Way Left to Go
description: Sotheby’s opened a new salesroom and international collectors are arriving for the inaugural Art Basel Paris fair. But visiting is one thing; buying is another.
content: “This is the Mona Lisa of handbags,” said Aurélie Vassy, Sotheby’s head of handbag and fashion sales in Europe, as she unlocked a glass display case and proudly revealed a battered black leather Birkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
title: China Counts Wild Pandas. Nobody Believes Its Tally.
description: The panda census methodology is widely seen as flawed, and China keeps the data shrouded in secrecy.
content: American zoos point to a rise in the wild panda numbers — 1,864 at last count — as proof that the tens of millions of dollars they have spent on conservation have hit their mark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: A Distant Planet May Host a Moon That’s Spewing a Volcanic Cloud
description: Astronomers have yet to confirm the existence of exomoons, but a molecular signal around a far away star offers some of the best evidence yet.
content: Astronomers have identified thousands of planets orbiting distant stars using sophisticated observatories. But there’s something they have yet to spot with any certainty: moons around those worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Johnatan Reiss
title: Israeli Court Orders Government to Explain System for Medical Evacuations From Gaza
description: Three Israeli human rights groups filed a petition after the closure of the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, slowing the evacuation of patients.
content: Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered the Israeli government to explain why there appears to be no comprehensive system in place to facilitate evacuations of sick Gazans who are not involved in the Hamas-Israel war to other countries for needed treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Warns Israel to Increase Aid to Gaza or Face Consequences
description: The warning was conveyed in a letter sent Sunday to two top Israeli officials that included the possibility of a cutoff of U.S. military aid, officials said.
content: The Biden administration warned Israel over the weekend that a failure to allow the delivery of more humanitarian aid within 30 days to the nearly two million people trapped in Gaza could trigger a cutoff of military aid, U.S. officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald L. Kohn
title: Want More Inflation? Go Ahead, Let Presidents Meddle With the Fed
description: When presidents try to influence the central bank, they tend to push for lower interest rates — and that’s the problem.
content: Former President Donald Trump wants a say in monetary policy decisions. He has tried to clarify that his goal is simply to give his opinion. But we know that he was upset with and opposed to the Federal Reserve’s recent decision to lower interest rates by half of a percentage point and that he toyed with firing the Fed’s chair, Jerome Powell, in his first term. Moreover, Mr. Trump’s supporters apparently have compiled a list of proposals that give the former president new ways to exert influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Nearly 100 People Are Still Missing in North Carolina After Hurricane Helene
description: Search and rescue teams are still looking for the missing, officials said, with 95 deaths already attributed to the storm’s wrath in the state.
content: About 100 people remain missing in North Carolina more than two weeks after Hurricane Helene ravaged the western stretch of the state, Gov. Roy Cooper said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: As Harris Visits Detroit, Some Democrats See Ground To Be Made Up
description: Democrats have long won by wide margins in Detroit, but some party leaders said the vice president needed to do more to counter an assertive Trump campaign.
content: The playbook for Democrats in Michigan has been the same for decades. To carry the crucial swing state, they need to run up huge margins in its largest city, Detroit, where President Biden received 94 percent of the vote in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Push for Minority Voters and the Undecided
description: Readers write about Black, Latino and undecided voters in the 2024 campaign. Also: Protection for health workers; a father’s books; Japan’s birthrate.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Tom Mashberg
title: These Twin Marvels of Art Conservation Are Now Seen as Looted Works
description: The Met Museum returned an ancient cup, assembled from fragments, to Italy in 2022 after investigators found it had been looted. Now a second has been returned after a similar determination.
content: Their restoration has been embraced as a remarkable testament to the skill of art conservators who identified disparate, ancient pottery fragments and used them to recreate the treasures of antiquity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A 21-Year-Old Violinist Emerges From a Field Crowded With Prodigies
description: The violinist Maria Dueñas has something to say, and the skill to say it brilliantly. She makes her solo recital debut at Carnegie Hall this month.
content: The stage of the Felsenreitschule, a theater carved from the side of a mountain in Salzburg, Austria, is about 130 feet wide. During concerts, artists come out from catacombs at the side, beginning a walk to the center that, depending on nerves, can feel punishingly long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Paul Mozur
title: The Battle Over Who Controls the Internet
description: We explore an important shift in the yearslong struggle.
content: For years, the battle between governments and tech giants has played out behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and David McCabe
title: Trump Signals Skepticism of Google Breakup, Citing Competition With China
description: The former president also said he would do “something” to make Google “more fair” if he regained the presidency.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, whose administration sued Google over allegations it violated antitrust law, indicated that he might not break up the company if he regained the presidency, describing it as a bulwark against China’s technology ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Marking the Spot Where Desi Arnaz of ‘I Love Lucy’ Played the Conga
description: A new historical marker in Miami Beach pays tribute to his younger years, before Hollywood, when as a Cuban émigré he performed at a nightclub.
content: Years before he played the charming and devoted husband Ricky Ricardo on the sitcom “I Love Lucy” and became a bandleader who belted out “Babalú” before audiences, Desi Arnaz was a teenage Cuban immigrant who struggled to learn English in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valentine Faure
title: The Defendants in France’s Rape Trial Are Telling Us Something Horrifying
description: The past few weeks have been a brutal reminder that ignorance or the claiming of it can be a convenient tool of the powerful.
content: It’s the case that has transfixed France. Prosecutors say that for almost a decade, Dominique Pelicot repeatedly drugged his wife and invited strangers to join him in raping her. The prosecutors say that she was assaulted by dozens of men as she lay unconscious and that her husband filmed most of the encounters and then filed the videos in digital folders, including one titled “abuse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King, Katie Rogers, Clyde McGrady and Erica L. Green
title: As Black Voters Hesitate on Harris, Democrats Race to Win Them Over
description: With a frenzy of activity, the vice president and her allies are trying to strengthen her support with Black voters, whose growing alienation the party’s leaders had not confronted directly until now.
content: In Atlanta, a group of Black entertainers and elected officials took the stage at a brewery to urge a crowd of Black men to support Vice President Kamala Harris. In Milwaukee, dozens of volunteers fanned out across Black neighborhoods to encourage sometimes skeptical residents to vote. And in a blitz of national media interviews and campaign ads, Ms. Harris herself made her case to Black voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Tina Brown, the Queen of Legacy Media, Takes Her Diary to Substack
description: She made her name leading glossy magazines. Now she’s joining the newsletter flock.
content: For some prominent writers, joining the newsletter platform Substack has become a declaration of independence from traditional news organizations, or an ambitious attempt to build a new model for publishing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Bobs His Head to Music for 30 Minutes in Odd Town Hall Detour
description: After multiple interruptions, Donald Trump cut off questions and seemed to decide that it would be more enjoyable for all concerned — and, it appeared, for himself —  if he fired up his campaign playlist.
content: Donald J. Trump was about 30 minutes into a town hall Monday night in suburban Philadelphia when a medical emergency in the crowd brought the questions and answers to a halt. Moments later, he tried to get back on track, when another medical incident seemed to derail things, this time for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Fesperman
title: Neal Stephenson’s New Novel Traces the Making of a Spy
description: “Polostan” sets up a historical fiction series about espionage and revolution in the early 20th century.
content: When the final twist of a novel leaves you more excited about pages yet to be written than the ones you’ve just read, the immediate temptation is to downgrade the pleasures you’ve experienced along the way. That’s the conundrum of assessing Neal Stephenson’s “Polostan,” an enjoyable book in its own right, but a trifle disappointing for the way it abruptly ends just as your interest is peaking in its intriguing main character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: That Plastic Skeleton Can’t Be Your Plus 1, Police Tell Car Pool Lane Users
description: A California Highway Patrol officer in the San Jose area recently cited a driver who used a Halloween-themed ruse to drive in a high-occupancy-vehicle lane.
content: Unaccompanied drivers have long used creative tactics to gain access to high-occupancy-vehicle lanes. Mannequins and masked dummies have been known to grace passenger seats as drivers try to fool California Highway Patrol officers and shave a few minutes off a commute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
title: Lebanon’s Hospitals Buckle Amid Israel’s Offensive Against Hezbollah
description: The United Nations says “the targeting of health and relief operations is broadening” in Lebanon. Hospitals say they have been forced to close or are struggling to operate.
content: It was 12:54 a.m., and Elie Hachem had not slept in days when the chief nurse at his Beirut hospital called him in a panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media Stock Surges, Nearly Tripling in Matter of Weeks
description: The sharp rise in the share price of the parent of Truth Social has added about $2 billion to the net worth of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Over the past few weeks, former President Donald J. Trump has become a lot richer, and so have shareholders in the social media company that bears his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Washington Post C.E.O. Elevates Deal-Making to a Top Priority
description: Will Lewis has said he has a mandate from the paper’s owner, Jeff Bezos, to grow the business, including through acquisitions.
content: For the last several years, The Washington Post has sat out the deal fervor that has swept through much of the media industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Walgreens Says It Will Close 1,200 Stores
description: The pharmacy giant said it would close the stores over the next three years and plans to “redeploy” the majority of the workers at the closed stores.
content: Walgreens plans to close about 1,200 stores over the next three years, its parent company said on Tuesday, in an effort by the struggling pharmacy giant to cut costs and change focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump’s Border Plans Are Light on Details but Strong on Fury
description: The former president’s sweeping immigration proposals face daunting challenges, but voters still trust his positions more than his opponent’s.
content: During a rally in Arizona on Sunday, former President Donald J. Trump left out a crucial detail when promoting his proposal to hire 10,000 new agents to patrol the U.S.-Mexico border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maurice Chammah
title: Telling the Stories of Wrongful Convictions, One Painstaking Case at a Time
description: In “Framed,” an advocate for the wrongly accused joins forces with John Grisham to tell stories of justice denied.
content: Jim McCloskey should be a household name. Years before the Innocence Project began showing Americans that their prisons hold countless people who have committed no crime, he was quietly gumshoeing his way through hard, obscure cases. Without him, it’s hard to imagine “Serial” or “Making a Murderer” or the rest of our current wave of prosecution-skeptical nonfiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: With $32 Billion in Aid, Native Americans Push Against History of Neglect
description: A pandemic relief bill set aside long-term funds for tribal lands that have lacked the tax revenue, and infrastructure, to spur businesses and wealth.
content: Cortez, a Colorado town of about 9,000 people tucked near the San Juan Mountains, has the trappings of a humble but healthy small-town economy: bustling businesses, congenial single-family homes, a park with grassy fields, a public pool, playgrounds, a pond and skate ramps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: 2 Men Accused of Killing 72-Year-Old While Posing as Utility Workers
description: Two men who said they were looking for a gas leak killed the man in his basement in suburban Detroit and bound his wife with duct tape before taking her watch and phone, prosecutors said.
content: Two men posing as utility workers looking for a gas leak killed a man and bound his wife with duct tape after being admitted to their home in an upscale Detroit suburb on Friday, the authorities in Michigan said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das
title: Trudeau’s Move Casts Light on the Reach of India’s Intelligence Agencies
description: The Canadian prime minster’s accusation of Indian government involvement in the killing of a Sikh nationalist signifies a sharp escalation in diplomatic tensions between India and Canada.
content: The accusation by Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, that the Indian government orchestrated a campaign to threaten and kill Sikhs on Canadian soil has cast a spotlight on the potential reach of India’s shadowy intelligence network, which has been known to operate mainly in South Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: What’s So Funny About a Dictator? Venezuela’s Comedians-in-Exile Have Ideas
description: A generation that fled political persecution and economic hardship is finding a way to laugh amid the pain.
content: Estefanía León, a young Venezuelan comedian, once wondered how she could keep making jokes amid so much tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Megan Marshack Dies at 70; Was With Nelson Rockefeller at His Death
description: She was at the center of rumors about the former vice president’s last moments, but she remained silent about their association until she wrote her own obituary.
content: Megan Marshack, who as a young aide to Nelson A. Rockefeller found herself at the center of sensational conjecture about the circumstances of his sudden death in 1979, died on Oct. 2 in Sacramento. She was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Patchett
title: Ann Patchett: The Decision I Made 30 Years Ago That I Still Regret
description: What was email but the chance for more friends, more love, more work?
content: Tee Minot, the owner of Christopher’s Books in San Francisco, wrote me a letter not long ago about the joys of owning a bookstore. In the end, she said that if she could recommend one book to me, it would be “This Is Happiness,” by Niall Williams. I checked the shelves of my own bookstore, Parnassus Books in Nashville, doubting we’d have a copy of a paperback from 2019, but there it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Harris Is Trying to Retain Black Voters’ Support
description: Also, the U.S. gave Israel an ultimatum on Gaza aid. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Kamala Harris traveled to Detroit today for a town hall-style event hosted by Charlamagne Tha God, a comedian and author whose radio show is popular with Black millennials. The appearance was the latest stop in a blitz of ads and appearances that the Harris campaign hopes will convince Black voters to stick with the Democratic ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore
title: Political Theater: 7 Shows That Wrestle With Cultural Issues
description: These productions are grappling with climate change, reproductive rights, the Arab Spring and accusations of sexual assault.
content: The stage has always been a political setting, whether explicitly or implicitly. The lights go down, and confrontation and conflict ensues. With the U.S. presidential election around the corner, and the political fractures of society on full display, recent theater productions have grappled with these difficulties head-on. Here are a few of the current and upcoming productions tackling loaded and thorny issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Julian E. Barnes, Eileen Sullivan, Kate Kelly and Devlin Barrett
title: With Trump Facing Threats, Security and Politics Intersect as Never Before
description: After two assassination attempts and amid threats from Iran, Donald Trump relies for his safety on the same agencies that he has long assailed as part of a hostile deep state.
content: He has been the target of two would-be assassins in a matter of months. The intelligence agencies have told him that Iran is still threatening to kill him, and Iranian hackers got into the email accounts of his aides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maurice Chammah
title: The Law Enforcement Officers With Surprising Power
description: As chief law enforcement officers, sheriffs shape how laws around immigration, guns, health and much else play out at the local level.
content: Four years ago I drove to a small town in rural Missouri to meet the parents of Billy Ames, who were suing the St. Francois County Sheriff’s Department over his death. An autopsy said the cause was a meth overdose, and jailers admitted they had strapped Mr. Ames to a restraint chair. While reporting on the case for The Marshall Project, I learned that other facilities had banned restraint chairs, medieval-looking devices that experts say can make it harder to spot a medical crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Let’s Take a Scroll Through the Home Page of 1851
description: The first edition of The New York Times reveals a world very foreign from ours.
content: To understand the present, immerse yourself in the past. Everything about today seems more contingent and less obvious when compared with how things used to be. “The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there,” the novelist L.P. Hartley wrote in 1953 in “The Go-Between.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Canadian Officials Testify on Foreign Meddling as Tensions With India Rise
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s top aides spoke at a public hearing a day after Canada accused Indian diplomats of orchestrating killings and extortions in the country.
content: Top aides to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Tuesday said that meddling by foreign powers into internal Canadian affairs was “an evolving landscape” and pushed back at suggestions that the government had been slow to respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Leans Toward Truck Driver Fired Over Drug Test
description: The driver, Douglas Horn, sued the maker of a product said to be free of THC under a federal racketeering law, saying he had suffered a business injury.
content: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday over whether a truck driver fired for failing a drug test after using a “wellness product” which was falsely advertised to be free of THC may sue the manufacturer under a federal racketeering law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: ‘We Are Not a Monolith’: Black Artists Gather at the Philharmonic
description: An Afromodernism festival at the New York Philharmonic shines a light on Black artists, who are vastly underrepresented in classical music.
content: At the New York Philharmonic’s festival Afromodernism: Music of the African Diaspora, the composer Nathalie Joachim plans to showcase the richness of Black musical expression, like Haitian funeral brass bands, swing and New York Minimalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Clemente Bar Opens Above Eleven Madison Park With an Artistic Flourish
description: Bodai offers a Chinese vegetarian tasting menu, KF Seetoh’s Hainan Jones brings hawker food to DeKalb Market Hall and more restaurant news.
content: This highly anticipated bar and beyond, upstairs from Daniel Humm’s Eleven Madison Park, is a collaboration with the neo-expressionist artist Francesco Clemente. The artist aspired to have a drink named for him; Mr. Humm, who has many pals in the art world, responded with an entire cocktail lounge that Mr. Clemente decorated in situ. An abbreviated tasting menu ($225) at the counter is an option, as are vegan bar snacks like tempura fries and an agedashi tofu dog to accompany often elaborate drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Hard Truth About Montana and Jon Tester’s Senate Race
description: The state’s changing electorate and America’s polarized politics have turned Montana’s Senate race into the most consequential of the year.
content: “This election is about making sure we can have a state that is the same state that we grew up in,” Senator Jon Tester warned a group of Montanans packed into a local Democratic field office in Great Falls one chilly evening last month, just 35 days from Election Day. Ticking through priorities like protecting rural health care and supporting veterans, he noted, “You can’t get all this stuff done with somebody who doesn’t really understand Montana.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcela Valdes
title: What a Crackdown on Immigration Could Mean for Cheap Milk
description: Undocumented labor quietly props up the entire American economy — but nowhere more dramatically than on dairy farms.
content: Four-thirty in the morning felt numbingly cold in southern Idaho when it was Rosa’s turn to usher the cows into the milking parlor. Striding through the dairy farm’s open lots, she tried to balance speed with caution. April showers and the hooves of roughly 2,000 cows had transformed whole sections of the lots into a slippery goo of dirt, dung and urine. The muck stuck to her rubber boots; it was treacherous. On at least one occasion, she had fallen in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: There’s No Hot Wing Like a Korean American Atlanta Hot Wing
description: Smaller, lighter and sharper than Buffalo wings, this interpretation of a classic has faded away over time. But you can make it at home.
content: There was a time in Hank Kim’s life when eating hot, crisp-fried chicken wings every day was the norm — he could easily down about 20 in a sitting — not least because his family opened a wing shop, Cafe Hot Wing, in 1988.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Eric Lee
title: Giant Pandas From China Return to National Zoo in Washington, D.C.
description: A motorcade through the capital revived “panda diplomacy” between Washington and Beijing for the first time in nearly a year.
content: A pair of pandas from China arrived at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington on Tuesday, in a revival of so-called panda diplomacy after an 11-month pause that had left countless zoogoers disappointed by the absence of the lovable black-and-white bears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Could the Lone Fed Dissenter Be in Line for a Powerful Role if Trump Wins?
description: Michelle Bowman, a Trump-appointed Fed official recently cited by JD Vance, has been gaining prominence.
content: When Senator JD Vance wanted to back up the assertion he made during the vice-presidential debate that new immigrants are exacerbating America’s housing affordability crisis, he cited a Federal Reserve study. Except it wasn’t a study. It was a speech by Michelle Bowman, a Fed governor appointed by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Steely Determination
description: Lindsay Rosenblum’s Crossword debut is a hit.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The View of the Election from One Philly Barbershop
description: A round-table event offers a glimpse of the challenges Harris faces and the effort to overcome them.
content: Nicolas O’Rourke is no fan of former President Donald Trump, but he wanted to talk about him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Robert Jimison and Jessica Metzger
title: Optimism on Wall Street, and Harris Agrees to a Fox News Interview
description: Plus, an investigation into China’s panda factories.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: The Flood-Protection Rule That Trump Rolled Back
description: A Trump-era rollback of flood-protection rules has left critical infrastructure projects at higher risk, experts say.
content: In the summer of 2017, Donald Trump stood in the lobby of Trump Tower and declared he would heal a “massive self-inflicted wound on our country” by eliminating red tape that he said was making construction in America an arduous, expensive process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,215
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Oct. 16, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Profits Leap at Goldman Sachs as Banks See Steady Economy
description: The investment bank earned more than expected in the latest quarter, a theme for other big banks, too.
content: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported a monster jump in its third-quarter earnings, reaping $3 billion in profits — far higher than what Wall Street analysts had expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Small Business Administration Depletes Disaster Loan Funds
description: Federal officials urged people to keep applying for the loans, which they said they would continue to process while awaiting more funding from Congress, which is not set to reconvene until Nov. 12.
content: The Small Business Administration has run out of funds to provide low-interest loans to homeowners and businesses to repair property damaged by disasters, the Biden administration said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Learning With: ‘Test Your Focus: Can You Spend 10 Minutes With One Painting?’
description: Are you easily distracted? If so, you’re in luck! This lesson will help you practice your ability to pay attention.
content: Featured Article: “Test Your Focus: Can You Spend 10 Minutes With One Painting?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: They Were Driving Through a Tunnel. Then the Water Rushed In.
description: A leak in the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and the race to plug it revealed the fragility of New York City’s aging transportation network.
content: Titus Ogilvie-Laing was driving through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel last month in his beekeeping company’s van when he spotted something alarming. A stream of water was blasting out of the ceiling and pouring onto the enclosed roadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A House for One That Has Room for Many
description: When a woman made her weekend place on Long Island her full-time residence, she had it redesigned to fit her new life, and to allow for lots of friends to visit.
content: When Susan K. Reed bought a house in North Haven, N.Y., in 2002, she viewed it as a fun escape from her primary home in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel Tells U.S. It Won’t Hit Iran’s Oil or Nuclear Sites in Next Attack, Officials Say
description: Instead, Israel has agreed to focus its next attack on military targets in Iran, the officials said.
content: The Israeli government has told the Biden administration that it will avoid striking nuclear enrichment and oil production sites when it makes its initial response to Iran’s recent missile attack, two officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: A Lawyer Seeking Sean Combs Accusers via Hotline Files 6 Lawsuits
description: The Houston lawyer Tony Buzbee filed suits in New York with new allegations of rape and sexual assault from 1995 to 2021. Mr. Combs denied the accusations.
content: The embattled music mogul Sean Combs is facing six more sexual assault lawsuits in New York, including one from a man who accused Mr. Combs of groping his genitals when he was 16, in what a team of lawyers say are the first filings from dozens of plaintiffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas and Mohamed Sadek
title: Alvin Ailey’s Silky Creatures of the Night
description: Two dancers from the Ailey company perform part of “Night Creature” on the roof of the Whitney Museum, where the choreographer is the subject of a major exhibition.
content: This portion of the dance is set to the second movement of Duke Ellington’s three-part “Night Creature.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Could Weight-Loss Drugs Help Get People Back to Work? The U.K. Wants to Find Out.
description: The British government announced a multimillion dollar pharmaceutical partnership with Eli Lilly, including a trial that will study the impact of a weight-loss drug on work and productivity.
content: Around one in four adults in Britain is obese, according to estimates from the country’s National Health Service, and the problem costs the public health care system billions every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Harris Needs a Closing Argument. Here’s One.
description: Trump turned us into a nation of haters. He’ll do it again if he wins next month.
content: It’s time for Kamala Harris to deliver her closing argument for why she deserves to be the next president. Here’s what I think she should say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Therapeutic Food Shortage Puts African Children at Risk of Starvation, U.N. Agency Says
description: Supplies of a highly nutritious treatment are running out, according to UNICEF.
content: Nearly two million children may die of malnutrition because a product used to treat the condition is in short supply, the United Nations Children’s Fund said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Says It Would Be a ‘Smart Thing’ if He Had Talked to Putin
description: Donald J. Trump declined to comment on whether he’d talked with the Russian president since leaving office. But he added, “If I have a relationship with people, that’s a good thing.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday repeatedly dodged a question about whether he had spoken to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after his presidency ended but added that it would have been a “smart thing” if he had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Would a Strong Job Market Stop Fed Rate Cuts? This Official Says No.
description: Mary C. Daly, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said that the central bank shouldn’t act “out of fear.”
content: Federal Reserve officials predicted at their last meeting that they would make two more quarter-point rate cuts before the end of 2024 as inflation continued to slow and the job market cooled further.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: concurrent
description: This word has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word concurrent has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 13 in “Missing a Global Climate Target Could Spell Disaster for These Polar Bears” by Austyn Gaffney:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colleen Creamer
title: Caves, Waterfalls and Loretta Lynn’s Ranch: Three Day Trips From Nashville
description: Fall is the perfect time to take excursions from bustling Music City into the surrounding countryside, where a variety of natural and cultural adventures await.
content: Little more than a decade ago, Nashville, a.k.a. Music City, wasn’t so much a tourist town as it was a destination for musicians — a place where performers like Taylor Swift could still play the Bluebird Cafe without creating a scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: What Should a Music Magazine Be in the TikTok Era? Pitchfork Alumni Have an Idea.
description: After the popular publication was folded into GQ, a group of them is striking out on its own. One of the first orders of business: doing away with album scores.
content: For more than a quarter century, Pitchfork was a kind of Rolling Stone for the millennial generation, a bible for audiophiles whose authority was summed up by its simple slogan: “the most trusted voice in music.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Hail, Salmon Caesar
description: This clever recipe from Jerrelle Guy comes with both a secret ingredient and a timesaving twist.
content: Over here at New York Times Cooking, we’ve been rhapsodizing about fall lately: the apples, the soups, the stews, the roast chickens, the chill in the air, the sweater season of it all. But our readers are all over the United States and abroad, too, and it may not be your time to shrug on some fleece. It may, in fact, be pretty hot out where you are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Ted Cruz and Colin Allred Face Off in Texas Senate Debate
description: The candidates engaged in a fiery but substantive matchup on Tuesday night, as polls showed Mr. Cruz with a slight lead.
content: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and his Democratic opponent, Representative Colin Allred, sparred over abortion and the border in a fiery and substantive televised debate on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Underappreciated Sports
description: What athletic endeavors do you think deserve more respect?
content: Artistic swimming, formerly known as synchronized swimming, was one of the flashiest sports at the Olympics this past summer. But even though it is a crowd-pleaser and much harder than it used to be, it has continually had to make the case that it is even a sport at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: Prediction Markets Tell a Different Story From the Polls
description: Supporters say the platforms are better at predicting the election. But questions have arisen about recent big bets, as they show a big lead for Donald Trump.
content: Polls show the U.S. presidential contest as neck and neck. But a popular new way of tracking the race — and betting on it — is telling a different story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: K-Pop Star Testifies in South Korean Parliament About Bullying at Work
description: The appearance by Hanni, a member of NewJeans, was eagerly awaited, but she offered few revelations about her famously regimented industry.
content: It is rare for voices of dissent to emerge from within the tightly-controlled K-pop industry. So when one of its hottest stars was set to speak out about bullying in the workplace at a hearing in South Korea’s Parliament, expectations were high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Theodore Schleifer
title: Republican Operatives Function as Hidden Hand Behind Pro-Trump Efforts
description: A political nonprofit organization called Building America’s Future has raised and spent more than $100 million over the past four years.
content: A group of Republican donors and operatives has been the hidden hand behind some of this campaign’s most controversial advertisements attacking Kamala Harris and bolstering Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Adams Chooses Ex-Prosecutor to Replace City Hall Official Who Resigned
description: Chauncey Parker will replace Philip B. Banks III, who last week resigned from his role as the deputy mayor for public safety.
content: Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday appointed a law enforcement veteran as the new deputy mayor for public safety to replace Philip B. Banks III, who resigned last week as corruption investigations intensified at City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Can the Stock Market Keep Going Up? Market Watchers Think So.
description: The bullishness on Wall Street is largely based on confidence that the Federal Reserve will tame inflation, the economy will remain solid and corporate earnings will continue to grow.
content: Stocks have climbed since the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates a month ago, with investors betting that it marked the beginning of a series of cuts that will offer a tailwind to the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Fanfare for a Common Building
description: An apartment house on the Upper West Side turns 100.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at an apartment building that’s celebrating its 100th birthday. We’ll also look at a congressional race in upstate New York with a Republican whose rhetoric belies the careful, courteous and pragmatic reputation he spent years cultivating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Survivors of Maine Mass Shooting Take Step Toward Suing the Army
description: A group of survivors and relatives of victims said the military failed to respond to warning signs from the gunman, an Army Reserve grenade instructor, ahead of the shooting.
content: Survivors of the mass shooting that killed 18 people last October in Lewiston, Maine, notified the Defense Department on Tuesday that they intended to sue the military for negligence. Dozens of survivors, along with a smaller number of relatives of the victims, said that the Army had failed to responsibly address the shooter’s declining mental health and threats of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Holiday Sales Growth Expected to Normalize in an Abnormal Year
description: Despite shoppers’ election-year concerns and worries about the economy, retail executives predict sales to increase as much as 3.5 percent over last year’s holiday season.
content: The holiday shopping season this year is marked by abnormalities: a contentious presidential election, uncertainty about the direction of the economy and stubborn inflation. But despite those obstacles, retail sales are expected to be … normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Harris Uses Trump’s Own Words to Attack Him as ‘Unhinged’: ‘Roll the Clip’
description: At a rally in Pennsylvania, in a swing county in a swing state, Vice President Kamala Harris played clips of Donald Trump describing critics as an “enemy from within,” drawing jeers from her crowd.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s words thundered from screens at a packed campaign rally on Monday night in Erie, Pa. But the event was for Vice President Kamala Harris, who was using Mr. Trump’s own words as her campaign amplified warnings of the dangers she says he poses should he win a second term in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Mark Robinson Sues CNN Over Report Linking Him to Lewd Comments on Porn Site
description: Mr. Robinson’s campaign for governor of North Carolina has been in crisis since the report, which the lawsuit calls “recklessly false.”
content: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina, the embattled Republican nominee for governor, filed a defamation lawsuit on Tuesday against CNN, which published an article last month linking him to lewd and offensive comments made years ago on a pornography website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Lufthansa Fined $4 Million for Stopping Jewish Passengers From Boarding Plane
description: The Transportation Department handed out a record fine after the airline prevented 128 travelers from making a connecting flight in 2022.
content: The Transportation Department fined Lufthansa $4 million on Tuesday, after finding the airline had discriminated against 128 Jewish passengers traveling from New York to Hungary in 2022 by preventing them from making a connecting flight in Germany, according to an agency announcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: It’s Time for America to Get Real With Iran and Israel
description: A real strategy for coercive U.S. diplomacy to change Iran’s behavior.
content: Let’s review the latest headlines: The United States is sending an advanced antimissile system to Israel, along with U.S. troops to operate it. Iran’s foreign minister says there will be “no red lines” governing Iran’s retaliation for any Israeli retaliation for Iran’s latest missile retaliation. And reports from the Persian Gulf say Iran has quietly told Arab gulf states that if Iran is hit by Israel, Tehran may respond by striking Arab oil fields. If all of this does not terrify you, you are not paying attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Political Infighting Hampers Ukraine’s Efforts to Avert Energy Crisis
description: Top energy officials have fallen and key energy policy decisions have been delayed because of political calculations, lawmakers and experts say, costing Ukraine valuable time in preparing for winter.
content: For more than two years, as Russia relentlessly bombed Ukraine’s power stations, the head of the national electricity company, Volodymyr Kudrytskyi, earned praise from Kyiv’s allies and energy experts for keeping the country’s power grid mostly running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Need Help Understanding the Election? Try These Audiobooks
description: Gripping histories, cleareyed memoirs and satirical fiction can help you make sense of our political moment.
content: To read about a presidential election is to parachute into a nation grappling with what it has become — and what it wants to be. This fall, as voters face a choice between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump, the stakes can feel almost unbearably consequential. But it may be comforting to know that we have been here before: the rivets of American society straining, the national conversation devolving into a shouting match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Devastating Israeli strikes in Gaza.
content: Dozens of Palestinians were injured or killed by Israeli strikes in central Gaza yesterday morning, one of which hit the grounds of Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital, according to health officials and the U.N.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sternbergh
title: His Blood Test Predicted Felonies in His Future
description: Charles Baxter’s new novel is a snapshot of a troubled America, disguised as a speculative comedy.
content: If you’re brazen enough to slap “A Comedy” on the cover of your novel, it had better be funny. Thankfully — for the reader, for the author, for everyone involved — Charles Baxter’s “Blood Test” is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emilia Petrarca
title: Would You Wear $990 Slippers?
description: Luxurious versions of indoor shoes are leaving the living room for city streets, grime be damned.
content: In the summer of 2018, Justin Bieber made a habit of walking around New York City in what looked like hotel slippers. He’d worn them out before, but by then he went seemingly everywhere in a plush white pair: To grab a coffee, to a church service at Hillsong, even to the beach. The choice baffled fans. Why was a multimillionaire wearing something that many hotel guests get for free? And did he not care about dirt? He remained undeterred. Later he incorporated the accessory into his streetwear brand, Drew House, ultimately paving the way for what has become one of the biggest trends of the past year. If members of the fashion world were confused by outdoor slippers then, they have since embraced them as an answer to our post-pandemic longing for home comforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Local Officials Cannot Refuse to Certify Election Results, Georgia Judge Rules
description: The ruling cuts at the heart of a key argument made by right-wing activists since the 2020 election, when Donald Trump sought to disrupt the certification process as part of his bid to subvert the results.
content: A county judge in Georgia has rejected an argument by allies of former President Donald J. Trump that local election officials have the power to refuse to certify election results, finding the process to be mandatory and one that must meet critical deadlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Leans On Creative Bookkeeping to Keep Up in Cash Race
description: Donald J. Trump’s official campaign committee has a payroll of fewer than a dozen and has found ways for another account to pick up the tab for his rallies.
content: Donald J. Trump’s political operation has been taking extraordinary measures in a bid to stay financially competitive with Vice President Kamala Harris, deploying aggressive and creative accounting strategies that test the legal limits of how far a candidate can go to offload the core costs of running for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Is Still Waiting for Trump’s Medical Report
description: Kamala Harris’s health is said to be “excellent,” but the nation has yet to hear about Donald Trump’s. “Do you really want to see his X-rays?” said Stephen Colbert.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan
title: The Latest Hot Item on Wedding Registries? A New House.
description: More couples are asking their wedding guests to help them purchase a home, eschewing traditional gifts like small appliances and linens.
content: Push the blenders, cutlery sets and fine china aside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Harris Has Raised $1 Billion. Can She Get Donors to Give More?
description: The sheer amount of money Kamala Harris has raised in her run for president has had unintended consequences.
content: When 300 top fund-raisers for Vice President Kamala Harris filed into Philadelphia’s Academy of Fine Arts on Sunday evening for a 10-to-a-table dinner, they got to hear from Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Jaime Harrison, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura van den Berg
title: A Girl’s Death Sets Up This Novel’s Mystery: Did the Maid Do It?
description: In “Clean,” a domestic worker for a wealthy family tells her side of a tragic story.
content: In Alia Trabucco Zerán’s second novel, “Clean,” a 7-year-old child has died. Estela García, the maid for a wealthy family in Santiago, Chile, sits alone in her cell, pleading her case to the authorities who might be listening: “I’m going to tell you a story, and when I get to the end, when I stop talking, you’re going to let me out of here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Byrd
title: A Philosophical Journey With Clicks of a Mouse
description: The writer of the game Phoenix Springs says it touches upon two questions at the heart of Buddhism: What is the nature of death, and what is the nature of perception?
content: Reflecting on mankind’s long history with technology, the British philosopher John Gray makes a bracing assertion in his book “Straw Dogs”: “Technology is not something that humankind can control. It is an event that has befallen the world. Once a technology enters human life — whether it be fire, the wheel, the automobile, radio, television or the internet — it changes it in ways we can never fully understand.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Watch Took 6,000 Hours to Make. It’s Still Inspiring New Variations.
description: A new diamond-encrusted Vacheron Constantin timepiece is inspired by one of company’s most elaborate creations.
content: In 1744, at age 12, Jean-Marc Vacheron, the youngest son of a master weaver, began apprenticing for a prominent Swiss watchmaker. Eleven years later, he opened his own workshop in Geneva’s Saint-Gervais quarter, where he would eventually design his first key-wound pocket watch featuring movement wheels and hands intricately carved into swirling gold arabesques and an enamel dial marked with Roman numerals. But it wasn’t until 1819, likely while traveling through what is now Italy, that Vacheron’s grandson Jacques Barthélémi Vacheron met the Genevan watchcase salesman François Constantin; the two competitors quickly became partners. Constantin suggested adding jewelry to their timepieces to attract additional clients and, a few years later, their bejeweled creations — featuring amethysts, rubies and garnets — caught the attention of Prince Borghese and Victor Emmanuel I, the former king of Sardinia. At first, their watches for women were often embellished with gilded floral motifs and worn around the neck or pinned to gowns as brooches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Ka Made Rap on His Own Terms. Hear How in 7 Songs.
description: Remembering the hip-hop artist (and New York City firefighter), who died over the weekend at 52.
content: One of the great joys of being a pop music critic is being able to ingest an artist’s whole body of work, find the throughlines and themes and meaningful resonances, and then be a bullhorn, sharing them with the world. And perhaps the job’s greatest grimness is to do the very same, but in service of memorial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Kmart Shelves Emptied of All But Nostalgia
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 15, 2024
content: “It is the final chapter in the great American story of success and failure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Michael Levenson
title: U.S. Warns Israel of Military Aid Cut if Gazans Don’t Get More Supplies
description: The demand from Israel’s closest ally came amid reports that the humanitarian catastrophe in the Gaza Strip has grown still worse in recent weeks.
content: The United States has warned Israel to increase the flow of humanitarian supplies into the war-devastated Gaza Strip within the next 30 days or risk losing military aid, American officials said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Georgia Officials Report Record Turnout on First Day of Early Voting
description: Democrats and Republicans alike have crusaded for residents to get to the polls early as Donald Trump and Kamala Harris aggressively seek the state’s 16 electoral votes.
content: After weeks of fielding phone calls, text messages and direct mail pleas to cast ballots before Election Day, Georgia voters did not waste time: Within six hours of polls opening on Tuesday, the presidential battleground state had posted record turnout for the first day of early voting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know Where These Memorable Detectives Live?
description: Many crime novels are known for their enduring characters who keep coming back for more adventures. Can you place these five sleuths on their home turf?
content: Many crime novels are known for their enduring characters who keep coming back for more adventures. Can you place these five sleuths on their home turf?

author: By Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
title: The Panda Factories
description: In the 1990s, China began sending pandas to foreign zoos to be bred, in the hope that future generations could be released into the wild. It hasn’t gone as planned.
content: In the 1990s, China began sending pandas to foreign zoos to be bred, in the hope that future generations could be released into the wild. It hasn’t gone as planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Hvistendahl and Nikolay Nikolov
title: The Brutal Reality of Panda Breeding
description: Panda breeding has been highlighted as one of the big success stories in conservation: U.S. and Chinese scientists working together to increase the number of pandas released into the wild. But a New York Times investigation found that they have succeeded only at making more pandas for zoos. Individual pandas have been hurt in the process, and at least one has been killed. Mara Hvistendahl, an investigative reporter for The Times focused on Asia, explains how records, photographs and videos — many of them from the Smithsonian Institution Archives — offer the most detailed, unvarnished history of the program.
content: Panda breeding has been highlighted as one of the big success stories in conservation: U.S. and Chinese scientists working together to increase the number of pandas released into the wild. But a New York Times investigation found that they have succeeded only at making more pandas for zoos. Individual pandas have been hurt in the process, and at least one has been killed. Mara Hvistendahl, an investigative reporter for The Times focused on Asia, explains how records, photographs and videos — many of them from the Smithsonian Institution Archives — offer the most detailed, unvarnished history of the program.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Donald J. Trump cut questions short and started playing music after two medical emergencies in the crowd at his town-hall event in suburban Philadelphia.
